questions.question:
Question 1: You are working as the PHC Medical Officer in your village. Which of the following diseases 
would you not target under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.explanation:
The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) does not target the prevention 
and control of cutaneous leishmaniasis (also known as Chiclero's ulcer). NVBDCP is the nodal agency for the prevention and control of the following vector-borne 
diseases: • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis) • Malaria • Dengue • Lymphatic filariasis • Japanese encephalitis • Chikungunya. The logo of the NVBDCP: 355 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector 
Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis 
and Bancroftian filariasis. Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

questions.question:
Question 3: 348 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is carried out by the Drug Distribution Centres under the National 
Vector Borne Disease Control Programme for Malaria?
questions.explanation:
The Drug Distribution Centres are only for dispensing anti-malarial drugs, under the National 
Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) for Malaria. The organizational structure for the Anti-Malaria Programme is as follows: • Central Government: supplies DDT and larvicides. • State government: procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts. • District Malaria Office: is the key unit for the implementation of the programme. • District Malaria Officer: has the direct responsibility of IRS spraying operations and is assisted 
by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. • Medical officer of the PHC: has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory 
services. • Multi-Purpose Workers and ASHAs: carry out case-based surveillance and case detection in the 
community. • Drug Distribution Centres: only for dispensing the antimalarial drugs. • Fever Treatment Depots: collect blood slides in addition to the distribution of antimalarial drugs.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following statements is true regarding the surveillance system set up for 
malaria?

options.a: Active case detection is carried out when patients report with fever to the peripheral health
options.b: Blood smears are collected fortnightly during house visits by Accredited Social Health Activists
options.c: Antibody detecting rapid diagnostic kits are used for passive case detection as part of
options.d: Passive case detection at the Primary Health Centre is done by examination of blood smears

questions.explanation:
Passive case detection at Primary Health Centres (PHCs) is done by examination of blood smears. Malaria surveillance system: Active case detection: blood smears are collected by the Multipurpose Health Workers (MPHW)/ 
Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) on house visits every fortnight. Passive case detection: detection of fever case by collecting of blood smears of those that report 
to ASHAs or peripheral health volunteers.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following measures for controlling malaria is the Urban Malaria Scheme mainly 
based on?
questions.explanation:
356 
Sold by @itachibot The Urban Malaria Scheme is mainly based on anti-larval measures for controlling malaria. In 
Urban Malaria Scheme, urban areas with a population of >50,000 and a slide positivity rate of 
5% are included. The vector in urban areas breeds in man-made containers. Therefore, anti-larval measures such as 
larvivorous fish and larvicides are used to control breeding as the primary method of vector 
control. In rural areas, anti-adult measures, such as Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) is the primary method of 
vector control.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most efficient anti-larval method to prevent urban malaria?
questions.explanation:
The most efficient anti-larval method to prevent urban malaria is to cover overhead tanks and 
other man-made containers properly. This is because the vector of malaria in urban areas breeds 
largely in such man-made containers.

questions.question:
Question 7: The blood smear slides (A) and (B) prepared from a patient suspected with malaria are shown 
below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding these tests?

options.a: Slide (A) is used for estimating the parasite concentration
options.b: Slide (A) has been air dried for 10 minutes
options.c: Slide (B) cannot be used for detecting the species of the parasite
options.d: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for both

questions.explanation:
Slide (A) is a thin blood smear and slide (B) is a thick blood smear. Thin blood smears (slide A) are 
not used for estimating parasite concentration. They are used to detect the species of parasite. Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due to its high sensitivity and 
specificity. Jaswant Singh Battacharya (JSB) stain is used for staining both thick and thin smears. Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. The correct thickness 
is the thickness through which a newsprint is barely visible. It is prepared by slow-drying for 30 
minutes, which leads to hemolysis and distortion of the plasmodia morphology. Hence, species 
cannot be detected. Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium. It is prepared by air 
drying for 10 minutes and fixed in methanol. Thus, the plasmodia morphology is not distorted. 357 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: The following two diagnostic techniques (A) and (B) were performed in a medical camp 
conducted for diagnosing malaria. Which is a true statement regarding these techniques? 350 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Image (A) - It is used for identifying the species of the malarial parasite
options.b: Image (A) - It is not the established method of choice for diagnosing malaria in urban areas
options.c: Image (B) - Antibody detection by this test is the method of choice for diagnosing malaria in
options.d: Image (B) - Bivalent type of this test was used for detecting Plasmodium falciparum and

questions.explanation:
Image (A) is a thick blood smear and Image (B) is the Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT). Bivalent RDTs 
detect P. falciparum and P. vivax. Thin blood smear is used to identify the particular infecting species. Thick blood smear is used to 
detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. Antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) are not the method of choice anymore in 
diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas. The Antigen detecting RDTs and blood smear 
examination are the recommended methods for diagnosis of malaria. Note: According to the announcement by Union Health Ministry in April 2018, antibody detecting 
Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) for malaria is banned due to the high false-positive rates in 
endemic areas. Malaria Antigen detecting Rapid Diagnostic Test kit:

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following parameters would you use to check the efficiency of the surveillance 
system for malaria under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.explanation:
The Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER) is used to check the efficiency of the surveillance 
system for malaria. It takes into account the number of slides examined for the population under 
surveillance.

questions.question:
Question 10: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India, states are classified 
based on which of the following parameters?
questions.explanation:
358 
Sold by @itachibot The annual parasite incidence (API) is used in classifying states/UTs according to the National 
Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. The Annual Parasite Incidence is calculated as: (Cases in one year ×1000) / (Population under 
surveillance).

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is correct about the classification of malaria endemic states under the 
National Strategic Plan for Malaria?

options.a: The states classified under Category 0 are in the elimination phase
options.b: The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
options.c: The states with districts reporting API in between 1-2 per 1000 population are in the
options.d: The states classified under category 2 are in the phase of intensified control

questions.explanation:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the states under Category 1 of the NVBDCP to be 
in the elimination phase. Category 1 states are all states/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following months is observed as the anti-malaria month in India?
questions.explanation:
The anti-malaria month is observed in the month of June every year in our country, just before 
the onset of monsoon (transmission season of malaria) to enhance the level of awareness. World Malaria Day is observed on 25th April. Health days 
Dates World Tuberculosis Day 
24thMarch World Health Day 
7thApril World Malaria Day 
25thApril National Anti Malaria Month 
June World Immunization Week 
Last week of Apri

questions.question:
Question 13: A rural medical officer implements Integrated Vector Management in his village. Which of 
the following measures of vector control would you prefer in a rural area?
questions.explanation:
The measure of vector control preferred for rural areas is indoor residual spray (IRS). Under integrated vector management (IVM), the preferred measures of vector control for 359 
Sold by @itachibot • Rural areas include: Anti-adult measures, using indoor residual spray (IRS) • Urban areas include: Anti-larval measures, like environmental control by source reduction, 
chemical control (mineral oils, Paris green, synthetic insecticides, etc.), and biological control (fish 
species Gambusia affinis and Lebistes reticulatus which feed on mosquito larvae).

questions.question: Question 14: Select the correct option regarding Intergrated Vector Management:

options.a: Malathion is the insecticide of choice used for vector management
options.b: Larvivorous fish and larvicides are the main methods of vector control in rural areas
options.c: Long Lasting Insecticide Nets are provided in areas with API 5
options.d: Insecticide treated bed nets are supplied in areas with API 3

questions.explanation:
Under the Integrated Vector Management initiative, Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are 
provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) 5. Integrated Vector Management (IVM): • For adult mosquitoes: • Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are used as the main method of vector control in rural areas. The 
insecticide of choice will be the insecticide to which the local vector is susceptible as per the best 
available information. • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT, and in DDT resistant areas, three rounds of 
spraying are done with malathion. • For larvae: • Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban 
areas. • For personal protection: • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) 2. • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API 5.

questions.question:
Question 15: You are working as a medical officer in Jharkhand, which is endemic to the disease 
transmitted by the vector shown below. Which of the following agents would you prefer to 
control this vector in view of resistance to commonly used agents?
questions.explanation:
The image given is that of a sandfly, which is the vector for kala-azar. In endemic states 
with increasing resistance to commonly used agents like DDT, synthetic pyrethroids are preferred 
now. The four states endemic for kala-azar are Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal and Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question:
Question 16: According to the revised strategy for the eradication of kala-azar, which of the following drugs 
would you use across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection?
questions.explanation:
A single dose of intravenous treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is used across all age 
groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection. WHO will supply this drug free of 
cost. Drugs for Kala Azar: 360 
Sold by @itachibot • Single-dose intravenous liposomal amphotericin B for all age groups and for pregnant and HIV 
co-infected patients. • Miltefosine- an oral drug, once daily for 28 days. Contraindicated during pregnancy, lactation, 
and in women who refuse contraception. • Combination of miltefosine capsules with paromomycin i.m, for 10 days. Contraindications are 
the same as miltefosine. • The drug of choice for Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is miltefosine 100mg orally 
per day for 12 weeks. Ivermectin is used for lymphatic filariasis.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following statements regarding the elimination and eradication of lymphatic 
filariasis is true?

options.a: It will be considered as eliminated when the number of microfilaria carriers are less than 5
options.b: It will be considered as eliminated when children born after initiation of the programme are
options.c: India has set the target of eliminating lymphatic filariasis by 2025
options.d: WHO recommends dual therapy with diethylcarbamazine and albendazole for elimination of

questions.explanation:
Lymphatic filariasis will be considered eliminated when the children born after the initiation of 
the programme are free from antigenemia. Antigenemia refers to the presence of adult filaria 
worms in the human body. According to the Elimination of Lymphatic Filariasis (ELF) Programme, there are two criteria to 
consider elimination of lymphatic filariasis: • Children born after the initiation of the elimination programme are free from circulating 
antigenemia. • The number of microfilaria carriers is <1%. Following the failure to achieve ELF by 2015, the target set to eliminate lymphatic filariasis by 
WHO was 2020. To achieve the same WHO recommended the use of triple therapy for lymphatic 
filariasis. It incorporated ivermectin along with diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and albendazole 
instead of the traditional DEC and albendazole therapy, for the elimination of transmission of 
lymphatic filariasis. In 2021, WHO released the 'Road Map for Neglected Tropical Diseases (2021–2030)'. Under this, 
lymphatic filariasis is targeted for elimination as a public health problem by 2030. In February 2023, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare in India launched a nationwide 
Sarva Dawa Sevan or Mass Drug Administration (MDA) campaign to eliminate LF by 2027, 
aiming to achieve this goal three years ahead of the global target.

questions.question:
Question 18: As the medical officer in a Japanese encephalitis endemic area, which of the following 
measures would you not advocate for controlling its transmission?

options.a: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
options.d: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease,

questions.explanation:
Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese 
Encephalitis (JE) as its vectors (Culex) are outdoor resters. Prevention and control of JE include: • Vaccination • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs 
act as important amplifiers of the virus. 361 
Sold by @itachibot • Use of bed nets for personal protection. • Use of larvivorous fishes. • Using malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak. 362 
Sold by @itachibot National Health Programmes II - NLEP, NTEP & NACO
